												I'm giving this game a negative review despite loving it. The reason is that I want to draw attention to the negative sides that I don't feel get mentioned often enough.First of all, there are still bugs in the game. After so many  itterations, one would have thought that things like trading and contracts would work flawlessly, but nope, you'll still run into situations where you need a save file editor or create another GM just to get the game to follow hockey rules.My other and biggest issue is with the way this game compensates. Let me explain. I've been playing EHM since the very first version, probably spent thousands of hours on all versions together. One thing you have to realize is that this game is essentially a numbers generator, working with probability and such. Thing is, if you've been playing this game long enough, you'll find ways to build fantastic teams, with (probably)  the best coaching staff in NHL history and you can pretty much win the Stanley Cup with any team by your second, in a worst case scenario 3rd season. But! The game detects when your team or player start producing extraordinary numbers, and it will start compensating to keep things "realistic". Won too many Stanley cups in a row? Well, you'll lose in the playoffs, no matter what you do (tested by replaying the same saves when things got weird on countless occasions). You'll win with the same team next year, but the game won't let you win, say 4 times in a row, just because. Same if your team is scoring too much. Built a scoring machine with 1st line level players on your 3rd line? Well, bad luck, because you're gonna get punished by periods where your team will refuse to score, until your goals scored total returns to a "normal" value, then, without changing anything, you score again. Same goes with winning games. Winning 90% of your games mid season? Well, here's a drought, it'll end once you're around 75-80%, then you'll dominate again and the cycle repeats.Bloody hell EHM, let me build super teams if I want to, don't punish me for finding ways to work the system. Sheesh! What's the point in learning to play a game if it will punish me for that and promote mediocrity?Otherwise, I really enjoy this game and I value the work they put into it, it's a great game, but the compensation system can be incredibly irritating.

								Before I start the review itself, let me start by saying that I'm part of the potentially big group that started liking ice hockey on their youth due to the Mighty Ducks trilogy. Yes, I'm one of those. And yes, you can imagine which team I'm playing with right now, the Mighty Ducks.That said, here goes the review.GameplayThere's not much to say, considering it's a management game. Being from a well known developer, mostly known for the Football Manager (FM) series, you can expect to find some FM similarities. Any ice hockey fan, with an interest for managament games, will enjoy the game and will most certainly spend hundreds of hours playing it.The gameplay is just you'd expect from a managament game, allowing you to set tactics, practice, and take care of the team's transactions. You'll also be able to lose yourself with all the statistics avaiable, trying to find that change that will allow you to tweak your tactic. But don't think for a second you can just grab all the big guns and ram your way through! You can also scout for prospects and develop them, so you can later use them to win the cup, or just use them as a bargaining chip.It's your game, your team, your choice. Until you get fired.Pros Plenty details; Good trading and contract system, considering the AI doesn't scam you, or lets you scam them; Quick booting and load/save system; Has a nice number of leagues, and hopefully more will be added soon; The match engine is quite good, and entertaining, with a few minor problems (see cons section); Good tactical interface, with a lot of options that can make or break your streak.Considering it's Early Access, and they're open to suggestions, and also considering by the end of its EA state will be most likely be as polished as the FM series appears to be, I'll reduce my cons to what I've found in the actual game so far.Cons Sometimes the players flip out a bit on the 2D engine, and either just stop for a couple second, or during penalties and faceoffs they just ram into each other until they find a way to go to their spot, so the play can start; UI could be a tad bit better, as somethings are harder to find;  To withdraw an offer after all the parties have accepted you've to right click the player's name and manually withdraw it, as there's no "Cancel" option on the news screen, just a confirm option.VerdictI'd give it a 9/10 considering it's EA status and the series long hiatus. Tons of potential.If I'm not mistaken, they don't have the licenses yet, but you can easily get a "fan made" database to "fix" that.

Early Access Review
								After an 8-year hiatus, EHM makes its return via early access and while the game is very similar to its most recent iteration, that does not hinder or ruin the experience in any way.  As an early access game, this is a very polished and solid initial effort.For those who haven't played EHM, the game is a text management sim where you take complete control of a team and attempt to use your skills as a general manager to take your team to glory.  As the game is in early access mode, there are no official licenses or real players.  However, www.ehmtheblueline.com has a very nice roster set, logos, and real team and competition names that provide that.  Unlike NHL by EA Sports, you are the General Manager and do not control the players during games.  You sign free agents, hire coaches, scouts, and of course, trade as you desire.  Additionally, you can set your lines, practices, and tactics.  You also can promote and demote players between minor leagues and choose how to build your team.  As you're unable to control your players directly, tactics are very important in helping you win games.  The games themselves can be viewed via 2d mode where the players appear as dots with the puck, similar to the initial offerings of Football Manager 8 years ago, before it went 3D.  The game engine is solid and provides a decent way to watch games and observe your players.  The minor gripe I do have with the game engine is that it does look dated especially compared with how SI has evolved its Football Manager franchise.  Having said that, the fact that this game was developed as a side project by SI mitigates that gripe somewhat.The menus are cleaner than EHM 2007 although again, not as intuitive as the newest Football Manager games.  The other issue is that the game can only be run in one resolution which means that newer screen owners will not be able to view the game on a full screen.  Hopefully, that will be addressed in a future update.If you love Football Manager, Out of the Park Baseball, and text sims, you owe yourself the privilege in checking this game out.  For $14,99, you simply can't go wrong.  The more people that purchase this game, the more likely we will see official licenses and future releases.  If you're an armchair hockey fan who thinks, sleeps, and drinks hockey, you definitely need to check this out.  Disappointed that your team continues to build around a questionable core?  Fix it yourself in EHM.  You won't regret it!

												*** UPDATED REVIEW FROM EARLY ACCESS ***It's gotten much better since Early Access.The reason why I love this simulator is because it's constantly being updated, and it also has a Workshop hub which isn't even something I originally predicted this game having. The fact that they're doing literally everything they can to incorporate as many fixes; features, and updates with rosters, teams, and even more proves that this game will be timeless for quite some time.But again, it is only a simulator so if you want the real hockey video gaming experience sadly you got to shell out the money for a PS4 and copies of EA Sports NHL every year. Every bug I've ever seen has been patched quickly, every feature I've wanted besides a few have been already put into this game. Besides no means of easily adjusting Salary Cap, Rosters, and Attributes between Playing and Non Playing staff this game has basically everything needed for a proper hockey sim. It's expanding to more and more leagues, and they even update the rosters regularly.It's nice to see a game having such support for such a small fanbase, even the Workshop has all the facepacks you could ever need. So far it's kind of a slow start out of early access, but this simulator has limitless potential in the long run.Graphics: 10/10Everything is aesthetically pleasing and as cohesive as it needs to be, with the Workshop addon it's easy to get the team logos you want without much fuss. I've ultimately no complaints with the GUI, as everything works as intended and should.Engine: 9.5/10The speeds are as fast as they've ever been with as good looking of a GUI as you can get, completely optimal in every way. Injuries for some reason seem more reasonable, but still far too common. There must be an option to either increase or reduce chance of injuries, because I feel for the entire NHL league they are FAR too common.Customizability: 6.5/10The game is fairly basic even now, as I previously mentioned in my Early Access review there's no real way to edit the leagues completely. I'd love to be able to add, edit, and delete teams from leagues just to experiment around with them. Usually simulators like this will have a sandbox-ish feel, but I feel fairly limited to original concepts which doesn't really have a "refreshing" effect if you think about it. It'd be nice to at least edit rosters, and staff however - you can import EHM 2007 databases which you can edit at your own will but to be frank that's quite a bit of a hassle. Some more open modding support would be awesome as well, or at least - more settings to tweak. Few more complaints is there's no way to edit rosters, staff, salary caps, etc... It feels less like a "Manager" more like just a "Be A GM." This isn't to say the simulator isn't accurate and doesn't meet it's intended purpose, but Simulator and Sandbox are something that go hand-in-hand. Especially when you're trying to make things interesting, and have fun with different ideas. I raised this to a 6.5 from a 6, because a lot of the bugs preventing personnel customization and hiring were fixed (like hiring physio's + scouts from players.)Interface: 10/10Though the resolutions you can use do not have the ability to be custom, there are new selectable resolutions! Basically all the standard resolutions, but it's so nice being able to just play 720p on my third monitor. The GUI is quickly responsive, and very intuitive. Easy to learn after a few clicks around, and nice to look at. I use the minimal GUI without pictures, background images, and news images to speed up the sims a little. Still looks great, and runs very smoothly.Functionality: 10/10Although some of the resident errors still pop up every once in a blue moon, there are no crashes I've found yet. You can usually just mash right through the errors and the game will still continue to no fault, it's a rare a game can just work through errors so I have to say these devs did a spectacular job with this simulator.Sound: ?/?Sound isn't a necessary or objective need in a simulator game, by any means and will not be counted towards the score.Overall: 9.2The workshop support is astounding, hopefully some people will make some addons relating to being able to edit rosters; salary caps, etc... very easily. Being hoinest this will probably be the closest I ever give a review to any game being this close to it's objective "Perfect 10." The support is awesome, rosters are residually updated and tweaked. Bugs are fixed commonly, and so far the game lives up to expectations and standards and even exceeds. Being honest I can only imagine this game getting better and better with time. It's not common that a game will have the ability to be timeless, but a simulator like this probably could being given the right amount of "Tender Loving Care" or "TLC" as it ages.tl;dr: This STILL was totally worth the $15 I spent on it, in short.

								I don't usually write reviews, but this game is already so good and still has such great potential, coming from a die hard hockey fan, I love this game. Pros:Scouting - Scouting mission details can be changed like player age, position, or ignore well known players/prospects, and it really helps you find the players you need, whether you're playing as Arizona stocking up on talent, or Detroit looking for a diamond in the rough, or Montreal and you are looking for some proven foreign skill to boulster your roster for the cup run, you can find the players you need. You can also generalize the scouting by assigning a scout to a continent, or country/nation, or you can assign him to individual leagues, you can even assign a scout to a particular player if you'd like.Game simulation- You can choose to simply speed up games to get it over with, or you can watch the game real time and make tactical changes, line changes, etc. Line Changes/team tactics/unit tactics/player tactics- Wow. Just great. You can change defensive zone strategies, neutral zone defensive strategies/positioning, neutral zone offensive strategies/positioning, forecheck, breakout strategies, offensive zone strategies, and of course special team units like PP and PK. You can choose which player is le playmaker of the line, choose who takes faceoffs (which is great I'll explain further in), etc you have absolute control of your lines. You can also change individual tactics, so if you have two offensive players and a power forward on your first line, you can change the line to not body check often or hard, and not be aggressive, then go to your power forward individually and make him check hard, play aggressively and with a high tempo to balance out your line, or set a defensive type of player to shadow an opposing player and keep him in check.You also have control over practice so you can train what coaches do what (coaches have attributes like coaching defensive players at 17/20, but then he might have 11/20 for coaching forwards and a poor goalie stat as well, so make him only handle defeinsive training. I believe it helps, clarification would be nice though. You can make certain player focus on an area of the game that maybe he is weak at, or boost what he's good at even more. You can have signing bonuses for games played, points, shut outs, etc.Those are a few things that stuck out that I likedCons:Now, I know you want it to be hardcore simulation, very in depth etc. But damn, it takes a looooong time to get through seasons. I want to go outside and do♥♥♥♥♥♥still, and have a life. I like it being in depth. Although I have quite a bit of time played, I find it extremely hard to get in to when it takes me like six hours or sometimes longer to finish the season. Just make an option to set a date a date simulate up to it. I know that's like EA NHL's simulaion, but it does work good. Or at least a quick sim game option. I know it might "dumb the game down" but the players that don't want it don't have to use it. Not everyone has time to play for six hours, although it's so good I have played for even longer in one session before. I really hope that isn't an option already that I haven't found lmao.Player Overall and progression- (My only semi-major gripe about something wrong/broken with the game, not having quick sim is not wrong/broken, it's just not included)This is pretty simple to understand why it must change slightly... I will have great prospects for the future, but they are young and only really strong in the physical category on the far right like speed, strenghth etc. and since they are so strong in that category, they have a four star "current rating" so if he's playing in the AHL he will be unhappy because he's rated four stars, but then I call him up, and he's a complete liability on the ice, and he does poorly in the big league, and his potential may drop or he may not grow properly. The worst part is, if you don't call them up they will get unhappy and eventually request a trade and in some cases not resign a contract so you just lost out on a valuable draft pick simply because he was being a cocky bigot (imporper use of bigot ik) that thought he was the♥♥♥♥♥♥ then his hopes got crushed and blames it on me. 												This is one of those niche games that most gamers probably wouldn't like but a certain demographic will obsess on. If you're a NHL or hockey fan. If you've ever played fantasy hockey. If you obsess on your favorite team and what would make it better. If you ever wanted to blow up an eternal loser like my Canucks (:sadface:) and rebuild the way you'd want to see it. This game is for you.I've probably played this game more than all other games combined in my life. I've spent literally tens of thousands of hours on this game since it's inital release in 2004 and it honestly hasn't changed much since then. There's been some tweaks here and there in the game's 13+ year history but it's still essentially the same text based sports management sim now that it was then. As someone who loves sports sims and I've played most of then, NHL Eastside is the absolute best and deepest one I've ever played. You control every aspect of the playing side of the game. Transactions, waivers, minor teams, drafts, personnel, strategies, contracts, scouting and free agent signings. The most engrossing thing for me has always been developing young players and working them into your system. Under your guidance players like Connor McDavid, Patrik Laine, Auston Matthews and other prospects can either flourish or flounder in your system.I'm not sure if casual fans will enjoy it. But if you're a hardcore hockey, sports strategy/sports management games fan EHM is a peak experience. Even today 13 years later, I still get the urge and thrill of spending an evening obsessing on this game fairly often.

												One of the best Management games on Steam. This game is an enjoyable experience for anyone who loves sports and likes management games. The 2D Graphics are smooth and easily followable, and the tactics are in-depth and provide a wide range of ways to play each game and develop your team. The game's tutorial is easily followable, but they could use some more added (especially the draft, that had me stumped a bit). The statistics portion allows in-depth analysis of all players in order to create your dream team and lead your team to victory.On the bad side, each game can somewhat take an overly long amount of time, even playing on fast and very fast speeds. The fast forward speed is what you will use for most games throughout the season. The difficulty is variable and on my first season I was able to win the Stanley Cup. I feel like they should make some new degrees of difficulty and they should allow us to change it (unless I'm missing something and just couldn't find the option)The game is surprisingly addicting and lovable, and the $20 price tag makes it completely worth it. Easily a better deal than the money-grabbing Football Manager made by the same developer as this game. So far EHM has not dissapointed me and I'm looking forward to more seasons.Overall I give this game a 9/10 as a lover of management games. If you're not into the Management series of games or if you're looking for a hockey game such as EA's NHL Series, this is NOT FOR YOU. If you do not like this style of game, you could be bored and you may not enjoy it at all. EDIT: I nominated this game for the Steam Awards and you should too!Thanks for Reading!-Joe "Bonzaijoe"

												There is so much that I could go on about regarding this game, but I'll try to keep this as short and as sweet as possible. This game is as close to the ideal hockey management sim there has ever been, by a long shot, and that can probably be seen in my hours played lol. The amount of detail and customization available in this game is staggering, and the ability to pick any league/team is refreshing, as taking over junior teams is one of my favourite features. The drafting/scouting system is very well thought out, and even acts like real life, with players falling/rising and teams drafting based on positional needs rather than BPA. Free agency can be a little iffy at points, with many core/superstar players all available at once. The salary cap rises very slowly from year to year, which is another issue, but it's a fun challenge to go along with building a dynasty. Developing prospects requires patience and playing them in the right spots, and it really is rewarding to develop a superstar, or watch a 6th round pick grow into a key player. Trading is good as well, as there will be times where you get 'ripped off' and others where you come off with a steal - asset management is a big thing in this game. The only complaints I have, albeit minor, is that if you draft well, the game gets easy very quickly, as you just trade good players for picks, let them develop, and repeat. As well, if you don't know hockey that well, the game may be a bit tricky to begin with, but the tutorials help with that. Additionally, the custom roster/logo//facepacks that come along with the game are very well done. I would highly recommend this to any hockey fan/sports management fan - 10/10, 2 thumbs up!

hurdles right off the hop that can turn off a new player, but if you get passed them, you should be on your way to a rewarding (and time devouring) experience.first hurdle is the lack of official licenses (except for, i think, EIHL & EPHL [U.K.]), but this is easily overcome with community made databases and picture/logo packs either from the steam workshop or from ehmtheblueline.  second hurdle is the menu navigation.  they have improved it somewhat from when the game was in early access, but given how deep the game can be, i think the menus are about as simple as they can make them.  all i can say for this is just stick with it, you'll figure out where everything is eventually.the challenges and depth EHM offers over EAs NHL GM modes is, in my opinion, like night and day.  admittedly, i haven't touched EAs NHL series since NHL14, but i'm guessing the GM modes haven't really been touched since then.  the biggest differences i can name off the top of my head are:the closest you can get to the ice is coaching, you cannot jump onto the ice during the third period and single handedly overcome a 4 goal deficit.  that doesn't mean that your team can't do it, you just can't do it for them.  this definitely ups the challenge since you can't cheese your way to the playoffs or a cup with a no chemistry bottom feeder team.there are no solid concrete "overall" or "potential" ratings.  there are skill ratings and statistics for you to scour over and determine how they're developing and if/where they will fit into your roster.  you also have scouts, trainers, coaches, and assistant GM that will give you a fair idea of how good a player is or their potential, but like real world, they can sometimes be very wrong.  i've had players that all my staff said were going to be a first line talent or starting goalie go completely bust, and i've had players that staff said had 4th line or no potential turn out consistent 50+ point seasons.i also find trading and free agency to be far more difficult.  there are no interest meters for free agents and they may sign with another team for more than they requested when you offered.  sometimes your UFAs want to test out free agency, or just don't want to play for you anymore.  sometimes your foreign prospects wont be willing to leave their countries or teams.  you're also unlikely to be the clear cut immediate winner in a trade, especially if you're the one proposing it and the player you're offering for isn't on the trading block.  trading up 1:1 for a slightly better player is rare and you're not going to get to Crosby, Kane, Stamkos, Karlsson, Price, etc. this way.anyway, i think that covers most of the important stuff and i'm getting sick of typing.  if you want something deeper than EAs NHL GM modes and are willing/determined enough to get passed the initial hurdles, there's a potentially very addicting game that awaits... just look at my play time.

Early Access Review
								DISCLAIMER: I want to start out by noting a couple of things that may be relevant to people interesed in this game. First, I never played Football Manager in any form, nor did I play this game's old 2007 iteration. I had no biases coming into this game. Second, while I am a hockey fan (Go Bolts!) I was not a hardcore fan. I was (and largely am) still fairly casual in that I don't follow mundane stats, am not up to date on every player in the league and don't watch every single game. That being said. This game is fantastic! I am having loads of fun with this gaming experience and as far as I can tell will be having lots of fun for months if not years to come. Who would like this game? - anyone who enjoys management games- anyone who enjoys stats and tactical games- any sports fans (hockey is a plus!) PROS:- addictive gameplay that makes you feel involved and responsible for your teams success and failure- a "one more turn" type of pull (days are done in turns)- a unique and highly realistic game simulator that you can watch in real time or sped up (highly entertaining)- HEAPS of potential, this game is still in Early Access but it is very fun and playable in it's current state, updates will only launch it to new heights- in depth stats and tactics including fully realized and modeled shot analysis for games (impressive)CONS:- confusing and unoptimized UI (needs streamlining)- can't control players yourself (this should go without saying but some people don't come to grips with this concept until they're in game)- lack of useful tutorial and helpful tooltips (had to bumble around some things before finding them out myself)- no sounds except crowd noise (might benefit from certain ambient sounds a calm musical track)All in all this game as it stands is great and will only continue to get better over time. It's a low price, can be played in short bursts or long stretches, has an addictive one more turn type of gameplay that makes you feel involved and connected to your team. I love it. 8.5/10

Early Access Review
								I've been playing this series since FHM 2005, although it was FHM 2007 that I put in hundreds of hours.  This version of the game is an iterative improvement over FHM 2007.  It appears to be a conservative migration to SI's latest app engine, but maintains a very similar flow to EHM 2007, not the latest Football Manager game.With that said, this game is simply spectacular.  I've only played a few games into my season with this version (so I'm not an authority on the state of completeness) but what I've seen so far is fantastic.  I've had some gripes with FHM 2007, fortunately it appears that quite a few of them have been addressed.  The fact that SI is bringing this game back is astonishing considering how they unceremoniously dropped the game after pirating concerns shortly after it was released in 2006.  Those of us with the Mac version really got screwed since there were some terrible bugs that were never fixed.Regardless, I'm really excited for the future... If this game gets half the attention FM gets, we're in for a treat.  I have a feeling what we are playing now is a wait-and-see product- see what the respose is to this conservative effort and decide if it's worth investing any additional effort.  Judging from the response so far it should be a resounding YES, this game deserves 1st class attention!Anyway, newcomers from FM are going to need to be patient, the UI is no where near as mature as FM.  FM has had the benefit of many years of iterrative development... while EHM has been in stasis for 8 years.  Even if this release just brings EHM up to date and nothing more, we all win.  Hopefully next years release will start incorporating some of FM's ground breaking systems.  This game is worth every penny whether you are new to the series or upgrading from EHM 2007.  My favorite sports sim ever, hands down.

												It's an interesting game for certain.I'm a PC gamer at heart and so the only hockey games I've played in the last 6-7 years have been nhl 07 and 09 on pc . I enjoyed the gm mode in those games even though it was rather easy to play. I bought this game on steam when it was on sale thinking that it could be interesting. I find that it is an interesting and challenging game to play as especially when you are someone that has never played the game. I started as toronto in the single player model to get a feel for the game. So of course I attempted to do a complete rebuild within the first week, getting all types of high end draft picks and good prospects while keeping the few young guys and veteran players around that were worth keeping. I also went too crazy in scouting and signing young free agent players. So i rather quickly found myself in a situation where I had 65 players signed to contracts and as a result I had to start trying to move them elsewhere. I got it down to about 55 or so before I decided to start again from the beginning as toronto. The scouting and free agency system in place feel much more realistic and you have to be very careful about who you sign, who you offer tryouts to, what type of deals you make with other teams because you can easily get your team into trouble in the short, medium or long terms if you make a bad signing or elevate your risk of being fired if you make a bad deal (so far I found it's rather hard to make a "good" deal if you know you have to get rid a player for contract reasons or cap reasons). Teams are also very reluctant to give up high draft picks or prospects which makes the game very challenging and enjoyable in seeing how far you can push other teams in deals.If there is one thing one little problem I noticed it is that it's hard to get fired in the game. My toronto team started the season off well ending up in 4th in the conference at about the quarter of a season mark. Then they lost about 15 games straight with 3 of those games being in OT/Shootout. They are 14th in the conference right now. No mention from the board about what are you doing to end this losing problem, no companing from the fans, etc. Not exactly realistic.

Early Access Review
								9.5/10, almost the perfect simulatorI have to say, this is the best hockey simulator out there, by far. This goes way more in-depth than any other hockey GM simulator I have ever played and it is by far the most realistic of any hockey simulators I have played. The strategies mean a lot in this. In my first year of Tampa, Ben Bishop was terrible: 3.43 GAA and a .878 save percentage. I made lots of strategy changes that made more players defensively-minded and it raised Bishop's stats to a 2.75 GAA and a .902 save percentage. In EA's be a GM mode, the strategies mean nothing. You can't decide how a player plays, you can't coach the players, you only assign what lines the players are on and that is it. In EHM, you decide where the player plays, the length of his shifts, his shoot/pass ratio, his practice, almost everything. Overall, it is incredibly addictive. I only have two games on Steam: TF2 and Eastside Hockey Manager. I have played more TF2 than Eastside Hockey Manager, but Eastside Hockey Manager has almost completely gotten me away from NHL 15's GM mode. When you compare the two, EHM is by miles better, and it's still in beta. Bravo to the developers for making such an amazing game.Wishlist/Gripes:*The ability to edit players. No matter what simulator I play, there will always be tweeks needed to the rosters. For example, Cam Talbot has worse stats than Robin Lehner in this game which I highly disagree with. In NHL 15 on current gen, you are able to edit players and make the sim even more realistic. I would like to see a player editing option because I still find that there are players who are rated too high or too low.*More casual options. I think options like injuries, waivers, and an assistant coach rotate goalies option would all be welcome in my opinion. I feel that waivers make it a little too easy and they need some fixes. I have seen the following players in years one, two, or three get placed on waivers:*Marian Hossa*Jiri Sekac*Brandon Saad*Dustin BrownIf options like this are available then I'm stupid, just saying.*More simple simulation. I find it frustrating that when I go on a vacation the assistant GM completely takes over. I think there is an option that can turn him off, but it is still very annoying when I'm a cap team and my assistant GM brings in Marian Gaborik. And the coach will also make lineup changes when there is no injury which is annoying. I wish the simulation way more like EA's but at least it isn't a major problem.*About the injuries, sometimes it feels like the injuries do get way out of hand. I always see like one or two or tears a month and those are four month injuries. I remember on my Edmonton play through in year two I had an injury every other game it felt like. All were minor (thank god), but it got to be very annoying. I think injuries can stay because they add a lot of challenge (like when I lost Jason Demers to a damaged spine which is essentially a year-long injury), but turning down the frequency of the injuries would be welcome.

								This is my first time playing any PC sports managing game (However, I've been playing NHL GM Modes for the the last 5 years), and all I've got to say is that it is fantastic!It's incredibly easy to lose your time playing this game, and it's a game that, once you stop, you want to pick back up ASAP. Although it is not officially licensed by the NHL, downloading all the updated rosters and facepacks takes little more than 5 minutes, and is well worth the download. It makes the game much more enjoyable as you get to have players on your team that actually exist in the NHL.Being able to decide what your entire staff will consist of, from scouts to coaches to freaking physio guys makes the game incredibly indepth. The addition of being able to adjust specific coaching styles to specific players, as well as being able to adjust how each and every line performs night after night is incredibly indepth and rewarding as you lead your team towards stanley cup glory! (or whatever other trophy the team you chose is qualified to win, because you can basically manage every professional hockey team on the planet.)This is essentially a much more indepth, almost overwhelming version of EA's NHL GM Modes. Once you get past the learning curve, you'll see no reason to give EA $70 every year for essentially an updated roster pack. While EA's NHL games are losing features, this game is gaining more and more features every 2 weeks or so. Give your money to this team instead of EA, because they're converting your $17 into a much better game at a much lower cost than any of the recent NHL games. This game will likely cost you all of your free time, and may even dip into your... non-free time. 10/10

								First, this is an early access game so it is not a finished product.  It needs time and they have already made changes to the product to attempt to improve it.  I expect this to continue based on the history this team has.Second, Some have posted that "it doesn't have the features of Football Manager" but that is a ridiculous expectation for a game that is a third of the cost of Football Manager and has not had the number of releases as that game.Now that I got the disclaimers out of the way. It has some growing pains but it shows a lot of promise.The positives:+ It's a hockey sim, a market that is in dire need of a good product.+ The stats are believable.  Scoring and penalties may be slightly inflated but I grew up watching hockey in teh 80's so I have no issue with the increase in scoring.  A 4-3 game is more entertaining than a 2-1 game.  :-)+ The 2D view allows you to watch the action, or just highlighted versions of the action.  It still needs work but it has a bit of a feel like the old Gretzky Hockey days.+ Did I say it's a hockey sim?!?!?!?The negatives:- Issues with CPU GM's (players getting put on the trading block but when you inquire you get a message that says the player is untouchable; teams with cap room waiving star players, not overly common but it does seem to happen and in the major case that I saw it was said player from the trading block being waived the next day after my inquiry and said player was the scoring leader at the time)- 2D match engine could use some work, there are some times where the penalty being called doesn't seem to fit the situation or the play being made by the player with the puck doesn't make a lot of sense or for that matter the play made by the defender- The UI could use some work, takes a bit of poking around to find things

Early Access Review
								Although early access, EHM:EA is a very polished management simulation. If you enjoy hockey, or any sports gm games, you owe it yourself to pick this game up. From Version 15.0.1b (first early access version) here are some of my findings on the game:Pro's: - Has nearly all the features from the EHM 2007, meaning it already is the deepest hockey sim available.- Nice new touches like players bio information talking about players close friends on the team.- Nice tactical improvements like individual strategies for players-Tactical improvements for lines including choosing who would be the playmaker on the line.- Free Agency is much more realistic. Don't expect to always build your teams on July 1st, UFA's want money and term just ilke in real life.-Position's of players are more in-depth, including their roles like defensive defenseman, stay-at-home defensemen, 2-way forward, skilled forward, quick forward. This adds to the fun of building cohesive forward units.-Tons of international tournaments, take control of your favorite national team and try to build a team to bring glory to your country.-The in game match view has been improved and is very enjoyable watching your team battle it out.Con's:- Interface and menus are very similar to EHM 2007 so it is missing some more modern interface options.- Resolution needs to be improved for modern pc's- Scoring has to be balanced a bit more to 2015 scoring levels (its a bit too high at least in NHL games).- Missing leagues like the Swiss leagues, Russian MHL, and British Hockey leagues from 2007 version.- Coaches and GMs get fired a little more than in the real world.There are a few issues like the small window the game runs in and the interface definitely needs some modern touches, but the rest of the cons are minor. The positives far outweigh the negatives with this release. Please do yourself a favor and buy this game if you enjoy the sport of hockey and have ever wanted to build your dream team or test your management skill in the lower leagues and build a legendary story as you climb the ranks to finally leading your national team to world glory.

Early Access Review
								Don't be scared off by the "Early Access".   Iknow the tag has been abused by many devs in recent memory, but this is not really a new franchise.EHM is a game series that has been around since 2004 with EHM: Franchise Edition, and in spirit since 2001 when the original freeware EHM was released.  After EHM:FE, SI Games released EHM 2005 and then EHM 2007.  The fan community has kept 2007 alive and updated since then.  So this is not a brand-new, from scratch game.  This is a game built on an already successful core from EHM 2007.  Riz and the SI guys are not new at this, and SI is the company behind the super-popular, long-running Football Manager series.  EHM:EA marks essentially the 4th release in the EHM series after a hiatus of many years,There is not a more-detailed, in-depth hockey management simulation game available on the market, period.  As with any sports management sim there is a learning curve.  But once you get it, you'll be willingly sinking a whole lot of time into it.

								I supported this title expecting the same level of dedication to quality was one finds in Football Manager (not that FM is without it's issues - but it is a very good game); but this - EHM, is not anything like its sports management brother. This game is apparently a product from developed back in 2007. And it looks like it. Important features are buried behind menus and different screens and navigating to them is far from intuitive. So your left blindly clicking hoping to find what you need. To make matters worth, some buttons are links without a hover state. So it doesn't look like a button or link, and doesn't behave like one until clicked. I discovered some features this way be accident. You can filter some lists, but I've always found this buggy. Then there's how data is laid out, which is in a busy, packed manner. Wheres FM lays things out in easy to look at, well spaced datas, organized in a pleasing and logical layout; in EHM you have glaring or just poorly chosen colors that either flash or blend with the games background. And did I mention that to date you're going to play this in windowed mode in a display resolution harkoning back pre-1080p monitors? Yes. This game doesn't know what 16:9 is.The actual games are laid out on a 2d, with stick-figure hockey sticks glued to little circles. Albeit this is better than OOTPs rendition, but its a laugh-out-loud insult to those who enjoy the live 3d action of FM.I could go on, but, to end on a positive is the community. There are update rosters and all kinds of nuggets of info to be found at http://www.ehmtheblueline.com/forums/portal.php.To be fair, to date I've put in 10hrs and aside from the horrific UI - when you get the hang of it I did have fun. But I just find the interfaces learning curve to much work that it sucks all the joy out of what could be a really fun game.Honestly, if you're a hockey fanatic get this on a massive steam sale. If not, move along.

												This game makes me so angry. I honestly, despite 440 hours of mostly enjoyable gameplay, can't recommend this game to anyone.This game is so full of bugs it's stupid and what's worse is that the developer has seemingly abandoned the game altogether. When I first downloaded the game about a year ago everything was great. The dev released very frequent updates and bug fixes and everything was peachy. The game ran super fast and smoothly and while there were small problems there was nothing major that had a big effect on gameplay. These frequent updates continued until the game was finally released until December 1st, 2015, when the game was taken out of Early Access and given a full release. As a huge fan of the game I was super excited for this new "EHM 1". There were a lot of cool new features added and it was the biggest update I had seen thus far. Unfortunately EHM 1 would be the beginning of the steep decline in the quality of EHM. This 1.0 update was so full of bugs it was actually unplayable for a large portion of players. Myself and a ton of other users had to spend days combing online forums and google searches for solutions to the problems we faced. I remember being so frustrated that this huge update came out on December 1st but I actually couldn't play it until mid December, and even then I just kept playing a save game from an earlier version of the game because the new version was so messy.As if this disaster of an update wasn't bad enough, a lot of these bugs have gone totally unfixed even now on May 29th, 2016. Since the 12/1 full release, there have been only 3 updates to the game, the last coming out more than 3 months ago on February 17th. These updates were two minor bug fix updates and then a 1.1.1 update that added some new content to the game. The game is still in shambles, and the developer hasn't touched the game in more than 3 months. He used to release updates on a weekly basis, and now he doesn't release updates at all.Let me break down a couple of the major bugs that have made me want to pull my hair out, and keep in mind that this isn't all of them.- You can't minimize this game. If you minimize the game, or if some pop-up automatically minimizes the game you can't open the game back up. You better hope that you saved recently because all of your progress will be lost. This bug has been around since the December 1st update, and has been unsolved for almost 6 months now.- The in-game clock was completely ruined by the December 1st update. In EHM you can't play the games, you just simulate all of them. You can mess with the in-game clock settings to make it slow, medium, or fast. I can't speak for everyone, but my friends and I and a lot of other people I've seen on the online forums play the game on the fastest clock settings. We do this because we don't want to sit and watch a simulated game for a long period of time, we'd rather it just be over with as fast as possible. Before the December 1st update you could simulate a game in under 30 seconds and it was absoulutely tremendous. Being able to fly through games so fast meant that you could finish entire seasons relatively quickly and your manager's career would progress at a nice pace. The December 1st update made the clock much much slower than it was before, even on the fastest settings. That quick 20 second game suddenly took almost a minute or more to simulate. I get that a 50 second game still doesn't seem like much, but when all you can do is just sit there and watch a screen for 50 seconds you get bored really quickly. This bug actually frustrated me to the point where I just stopped playing the game completely for almost a month. It's a really boring game when you have to stare at your screen for a collective two hours and do nothing just to finish one season. Luckily I found a fix to that bug by tinkering with the settings, and I was able to play the game with a super fast clock again, until earlier today. My clock is now super slow again, and there is NOTHING I can do about it. I've already tinkered with the settings as much as I can and my clock is super slow. I'm sick about it.- The bug I talked about earlier that kept most players from playing the new update for a few days after the 1.0 release is still around for a lot of new players. Whenever you start up the game you get some error message that breaks the game. You can't open the game, you can't do anything until you go into the game's properties and change all of the resolution settings, just so you can finally open the game and change the in-game resolution settings, before you go back and reset your computer's resolution settings. You have to do all of this annoying tinkering just to be able to play the game! Come on Riz!This game is super fun, don't get me wrong. I've played more than 400 hours. Unfortunately this is a game I cannot recommend to anyone, as it is just a giant headache.I'm sure the developer Riz is working on other games, and I'm sure he's very busy. He's the only developer of this game and while I'm very thankful for all of the work he's done the fact of the matter is that this game is abandoned right now. There hasn't been an update in MONTHS, not even a tiny bug fix!! I don't understand why the guy would just let this game that he worked so hard on sit and rot.TL:DRThis game right now is a buggy pile of mush. Before it was taken out of early access it was absoulutely brilliant, but now that it has been fully released it has been completely abandoned by the developer. Only buy this game if you want to deal with a bunch of problems before you can really enjoy the game. Don't buy this game unless it's on sale.

												This game makes me so angry. I honestly, despite 440 hours of mostly enjoyable gameplay, can't recommend this game to anyone.This game is so full of bugs it's stupid and what's worse is that the developer has seemingly abandoned the game altogether. When I first downloaded the game about a year ago everything was great. The dev released very frequent updates and bug fixes and everything was peachy. The game ran super fast and smoothly and while there were small problems there was nothing major that had a big effect on gameplay. These frequent updates continued until the game was finally released until December 1st, 2015, when the game was taken out of Early Access and given a full release. As a huge fan of the game I was super excited for this new "EHM 1". There were a lot of cool new features added and it was the biggest update I had seen thus far. Unfortunately EHM 1 would be the beginning of the steep decline in the quality of EHM. This 1.0 update was so full of bugs it was actually unplayable for a large portion of players. Myself and a ton of other users had to spend days combing online forums and google searches for solutions to the problems we faced. I remember being so frustrated that this huge update came out on December 1st but I actually couldn't play it until mid December, and even then I just kept playing a save game from an earlier version of the game because the new version was so messy.As if this disaster of an update wasn't bad enough, a lot of these bugs have gone totally unfixed even now on May 29th, 2016. Since the 12/1 full release, there have been only 3 updates to the game, the last coming out more than 3 months ago on February 17th. These updates were two minor bug fix updates and then a 1.1.1 update that added some new content to the game. The game is still in shambles, and the developer hasn't touched the game in more than 3 months. He used to release updates on a weekly basis, and now he doesn't release updates at all.Let me break down a couple of the major bugs that have made me want to pull my hair out, and keep in mind that this isn't all of them.- You can't minimize this game. If you minimize the game, or if some pop-up automatically minimizes the game you can't open the game back up. You better hope that you saved recently because all of your progress will be lost. This bug has been around since the December 1st update, and has been unsolved for almost 6 months now.- The in-game clock was completely ruined by the December 1st update. In EHM you can't play the games, you just simulate all of them. You can mess with the in-game clock settings to make it slow, medium, or fast. I can't speak for everyone, but my friends and I and a lot of other people I've seen on the online forums play the game on the fastest clock settings. We do this because we don't want to sit and watch a simulated game for a long period of time, we'd rather it just be over with as fast as possible. Before the December 1st update you could simulate a game in under 30 seconds and it was absoulutely tremendous. Being able to fly through games so fast meant that you could finish entire seasons relatively quickly and your manager's career would progress at a nice pace. The December 1st update made the clock much much slower than it was before, even on the fastest settings. That quick 20 second game suddenly took almost a minute or more to simulate. I get that a 50 second game still doesn't seem like much, but when all you can do is just sit there and watch a screen for 50 seconds you get bored really quickly. This bug actually frustrated me to the point where I just stopped playing the game completely for almost a month. It's a really boring game when you have to stare at your screen for a collective two hours and do nothing just to finish one season. Luckily I found a fix to that bug by tinkering with the settings, and I was able to play the game with a super fast clock again, until earlier today. My clock is now super slow again, and there is NOTHING I can do about it. I've already tinkered with the settings as much as I can and my clock is super slow. I'm sick about it.- The bug I talked about earlier that kept most players from playing the new update for a few days after the 1.0 release is still around for a lot of new players. Whenever you start up the game you get some error message that breaks the game. You can't open the game, you can't do anything until you go into the game's properties and change all of the resolution settings, just so you can finally open the game and change the in-game resolution settings, before you go back and reset your computer's resolution settings. You have to do all of this annoying tinkering just to be able to play the game! Come on Riz!This game is super fun, don't get me wrong. I've played more than 400 hours. Unfortunately this is a game I cannot recommend to anyone, as it is just a giant headache.I'm sure the developer Riz is working on other games, and I'm sure he's very busy. He's the only developer of this game and while I'm very thankful for all of the work he's done the fact of the matter is that this game is abandoned right now. There hasn't been an update in MONTHS, not even a tiny bug fix!! I don't understand why the guy would just let this game that he worked so hard on sit and rot.TL:DRThis game right now is a buggy pile of mush. Before it was taken out of early access it was absoulutely brilliant, but now that it has been fully released it has been completely abandoned by the developer. Only buy this game if you want to deal with a bunch of problems before you can really enjoy the game. Don't buy this game unless it's on sale.
